criteria.description: Negligible or speculative gain (e.g., < $10,000 / year).
criteria.example: A small efficiency tool for a single back-office team with unquantified benefits.

criteria.description: Minor, localized benefit (e.g., $10k - $50k / year).
criteria.example: Automating a complex daily report for the finance team.

criteria.description: Moderate, measurable benefit (e.g., $50k - $100k / year).
criteria.example: Optimizing F&B inventory based on demand forecasts, reducing spoilage costs by 5%.

criteria.description: Substantial, high-confidence impact (e.g., $100k - $250k / year).
criteria.example: A slot floor optimization model that measurably increases GGR on one bank of machines.

criteria.description: High, demonstrable impact (e.g., > $250,000 / year).
criteria.example: A new player churn model that retains a small, measurable portion of high-value players.

criteria.description: No discernible strategic gain or alignment.
criteria.example: A project with purely technical benefits that does not alter competitive standing.

criteria.description: Internal improvement with no direct market or guest-facing impact.
criteria.example: An internal tool that improves the HR onboarding process for new casino employees.

criteria.description: Achieves parity with competitors in a key, visible area.
criteria.example: Implementing an industry-standard AI chatbot for routine guest service inquiries.

criteria.description: Significantly enhances a core strategic pillar (e.g., VIP service).
criteria.example: A new AI tool that assists hosts in identifying high-value players.

criteria.description: Creates a foundational strategic capability for the first time.
criteria.example: Building the casino's first-ever player personalization engine (even a simple version).

criteria.description: Negligible impact on operational workflow.
criteria.example: A minor user interface tweak to an existing, non-critical internal application.

criteria.description: Minor, visible workflow improvement (< 5%).
criteria.example: Automating the creation and distribution of a weekly performance report.

criteria.description: Moderate, localized efficiency gain (5-10%).
criteria.example: Streamlining the guest check-in process by using OCR for IDs.

criteria.description: Substantial, measurable improvement in a key workflow (10-15%).
criteria.example: Optimizing dealer scheduling to better match table demand, reducing overtime costs by 10%.

criteria.description: Major automation of a core manual process or error reduction (> 15%).
criteria.example: Automating a key part of cage reconciliation or using computer vision to reduce dealer errors.

criteria.description: Negligible time savings (< 5 hours/week).
criteria.example: A change that saves a few minutes per week for a single employee.

criteria.description: Minor, measurable time savings (5-10 hours/week) for a single team.
criteria.example: A script to automate a repetitive data entry task that saves one person two hours per day.

criteria.description: Saves significant, measurable time (20+ hours/week) but not a full FTE.
criteria.example: An internal knowledge base chatbot that significantly reduces inbound questions to a team.

criteria.description: Frees 1 full-time employee (FTE) for higher-value work.
criteria.example: Automating comp issuance, saving one full-time employee from manual data entry.

criteria.description: Frees 2 or more full-time employees (FTEs) for higher-value work.
criteria.example: An AI-powered surveillance system that automates incident flagging, freeing 2 staff members.

criteria.description: No specific deadline; can be scheduled flexibly.
criteria.example: A back-end infrastructure improvement project with no external dependencies.

criteria.description: Aligns with a future campaign or provides a first-mover advantage.
criteria.example: Launching a new loyalty feature before a local competitor is expected to launch theirs next year.

criteria.description: Addresses a major customer pain point or system degradation.
criteria.example: Fixing a significant bug in the loyalty app that is causing widespread customer complaints.

criteria.description: Important deadline (3–6 months) with significant penalties or lost opportunity.
criteria.example: A sports betting model that must be live before the NFL season begins in 4 months.

criteria.description: Critical, immovable deadline (<3 months) with severe consequences.
criteria.example: A project to meet a new Gaming Commission data reporting standard due next quarter.

criteria.description: Minimal cost (< $10,000).
criteria.example: A project using only existing software licenses and a few days of developer time.
A standard machine learning model build-out on the existing cloud platform.

criteria.description: Moderate cost ($25,000 - $50,000).
criteria.example: A project requiring new software licenses and significant development effort.
A project requiring new hardware (e.g., cameras) and a full project team.

criteria.description: Very high cost (> $100,000).
criteria.example: A major platform build-out (extremely high cost for a nascent team).

criteria.description: Negligible ongoing cost (< $500/month).
criteria.example: A model with low inference demand running on existing shared infrastructure.

criteria.description: Low ongoing cost ($500–$1,000/month).
criteria.example: A project requiring a dedicated cloud server instance for batch processing.

criteria.description: Moderate ongoing cost ($1,000–$3,000/month).
criteria.example: A project with significant cloud computing or third-party API usage costs.

criteria.description: High ongoing cost ($3,000–$5,000/month).
criteria.example: A solution requiring expensive third-party data or SaaS licenses.

criteria.description: Very high ongoing cost (> $5,000/month).
criteria.example: A large-scale, real-time system (a very high burden for a new team).

criteria.description: Negligible maintenance (< 1 day/month).
criteria.example: A 'set and forget' model that requires only automated monitoring.

criteria.description: Low maintenance (1–2 days/month).
criteria.example: Requires periodic model retraining and monitoring by one part-time engineer.

criteria.description: Moderate maintenance (approx. 1 day/week).
criteria.example: Requires a dedicated engineer to monitor, retrain, and troubleshoot the system.

criteria.description: High maintenance (2–3 days/week).
criteria.example: Requires a significant portion of one engineer's time for ongoing support.

criteria.description: Very high maintenance (1 dedicated full-time FTE).
criteria.example: A complex system requiring a dedicated maintenance resource.

criteria.description: Immediate or very fast (< 6 months).
criteria.example: A cost-saving automation with a clear and immediate ROI.

criteria.description: Fast (6–12 months).
criteria.example: A project with strong financial benefit that quickly covers its initial cost.

criteria.description: Moderate (12–18 months).
criteria.example: A standard project with a solid business case and predictable returns.

criteria.description: Slow (18–24 months).
criteria.example: A strategic project where financial returns are longer-term.

criteria.description: Very slow or speculative (> 24 months).
criteria.example: Foundational R&D projects with no direct, short-term ROI.

criteria.description: Directly enables a primary corporate Objective (C-level).
criteria.example: Project is the key initiative for the OKR 'Increase Player Lifetime Value by 5%'.

criteria.description: Supports a corporate-level Key Result (VP-level).
criteria.example: Supports the KR 'Increase digital engagement by 10%' under a broader Objective.

criteria.description: Supports a departmental-level Key Result.
criteria.example: Supports the AI Department's KR of 'Deliver 3 successful pilot projects this year.'

criteria.description: Vague or indirect link to an OKR.
criteria.example: The project is generally aligned with strategy but not tied to a specific metric.

criteria.description: No link to any stated corporate or departmental OKR.
criteria.example: An ad-hoc request that does not fit into the current strategic plan.

criteria.description: Creates a foundational market-leading capability.
criteria.example: A proprietary real-time recommendation engine (even a simple one).

criteria.description: Delivers a new competitive advantage for the property.
criteria.example: A new fraud detection model that is superior to our current manual process.

criteria.description: Establishes a meaningful point of difference in our service.
criteria.example: A personalized marketing engine that is noticeably better than local competitors.

criteria.description: Minor enhancement to an existing competitive advantage.
criteria.example: A small improvement to our existing loyalty program's mobile app.

criteria.description: Achieves parity; a 'catch-up' project.
criteria.example: Implementing a chatbot because all other casinos in the area have one.

criteria.description: Builds a foundational, reusable platform component.
criteria.example: Building the first MLOps pipeline or a 'Player 360' feature store.

criteria.description: Creates a moderately reusable AI component or feature set.
criteria.example: Developing a new, reusable feature set for hotel data that can be used by other models.

criteria.description: Develops a new data pipeline or model that might be used by 1-2 other projects.
criteria.example: Building a pipeline for F&B data that another team might use later.

criteria.description: Some learnings, but limited code or pipeline reusability.
criteria.example: A niche project with code that is too specific to be reused elsewhere.

criteria.description: One-off solution with no reusable components or lasting knowledge gain.
criteria.example: A quick script built to solve a single, non-recurring problem.

criteria.description: Proactively supports core license-to-operate requirements.
criteria.example: A project to enhance responsible gaming or AML detection capabilities.

criteria.description: Helps streamline or improve reporting for an existing regulation.
criteria.example: Automating the generation of reports required by the local Gaming Commission.

criteria.description: Supports an internal best practice for compliance or data governance.
criteria.example: A tool to better manage and document access to sensitive player data.

criteria.description: Neutral; no impact on compliance or regulatory standing.
criteria.example: A project to optimize F&B inventory that has no compliance implications.

criteria.description: Adds burden: Project introduces new compliance review requirements.
criteria.example: A project using a new data source that requires a new, complex compliance review process.

criteria.description: Minimal effort (< 40 hours); simple, well-defined task.
criteria.example: Building a simple Looker dashboard using a curated data model.

criteria.description: Low effort (40–80 hours); uses existing tech and patterns.
criteria.example: Training a churn prediction model using an established data pipeline.

criteria.description: Medium effort (80–160 hours); requires one new integration.
criteria.example: Integrating a new AI model with the casino's primary CRM platform.

criteria.description: High effort (160–200 hours); complex integration.
criteria.example: Pulling and processing real-time data from a legacy slot machine protocol.

criteria.description: Very high effort (> 416 hours); R&D with unknown scope.
criteria.example: A novel computer vision project for real-time table game analysis.

criteria.description: Data is trusted, clean, and ready in a centralized data mart.
criteria.example: Project will use the curated 'Player 360' data mart.

criteria.description: Data is accessible but requires some validation/cleaning (< 1 week).
criteria.example: Project requires combining several tables from the raw data lake.

criteria.description: Data is available but requires significant ETL (1–2 weeks).
criteria.example: Project requires integrating data from the hotel PMS with gaming data.

criteria.description: Data is siloed, dirty, and requires major integration work (> 2 weeks).
criteria.example: Project requires extracting data from an old, unsupported marketing database.

criteria.description: Hard Gate. Data is untrusted, inaccessible, or non-existent.
criteria.example: Project requires detailed video data from overhead cameras that are not yet installed.

criteria.description: No user-facing change; purely a back-end improvement.
criteria.example: Optimizing a data pipeline's performance with no change to the output.

criteria.description: Minor process tweak for a single, small, tech-savvy team (< 10 users).
criteria.example: Introducing a new dashboard for the 5-person marketing analytics team.

criteria.description: Requires process change and training for one department (10–50 users).
criteria.example: Rolling out a new lead-scoring tool for the 30-person casino host team.

criteria.description: Requires significant process change across multiple departments (50–200 users).
criteria.example: A new system for table game operations affecting 150+ dealers and pit bosses.

criteria.description: Requires org-wide policy change and retraining of all front-line staff (>200 users).
criteria.example: A completely new guest services platform for all 500+ front-line employees.

criteria.description: Full expertise and capacity exist within the current AI team.
criteria.example: A standard machine learning project using the team's core skills (e.g., Python).

criteria.description: Minor gaps; current team can deliver with minimal assistance (< 20 hours).
criteria.example: A project requiring a small amount of a DevOps engineer's time for deployment.

criteria.description: Requires significant help from another internal team.
criteria.example: A project that is blocked until the Data Engineering team can build a new pipeline.

criteria.description: Major gap; requires hiring a contractor or upskilling.
criteria.example: A project requiring a specialized reinforcement learning expert.

criteria.description: Hard Gate. No capacity/skills; requires a new hire.
criteria.example: Project requires 3 engineers but the team only has 1 and is fully allocated.

criteria.description: Natively fits the target tech stack (e.g., Vertex AI, BigQuery).
criteria.example: A project that can be built entirely using the established GCP stack.

criteria.description: Requires minor, approved extensions to the target stack.
criteria.example: A project that requires installing a new, but common, Python library.

criteria.description: Requires integration with a non-standard or legacy system.
criteria.example: A project that needs to pull data from an external server.

criteria.description: Requires procurement and support of a new, one-off third-party tool.
criteria.example: A vendor solution that needs to be purchased and integrated into the data ecosystem.

criteria.description: Hard Gate. Requires a technology stack that is disallowed by IT.
criteria.example: A project requiring a niche database technology not supported by the company.

criteria.description: Highly engaged Executive (VP+) sponsor actively removes blockers.
criteria.example: The project is championed by a C-level manager who attends weekly check-ins.

criteria.description: Engaged Director-level sponsor from the requesting unit.
criteria.example: The Director of Marketing is the sponsor and is readily available for questions.

criteria.description: Sponsor is at Manager level with limited influence.
criteria.example: A manager is the sponsor but defers most decisions to the project team.

criteria.description: Sponsor is disengaged or lacks authority.
criteria.example: The project was requested by a junior analyst with no clear executive backing.

criteria.description: Hard Gate. No sponsor; project lacks ownership.
criteria.example: An 'idea' from the tech team with no business unit willing to champion it.

criteria.description: SMART Goals: KPIs, scope, and success are clearly defined.
criteria.example: 'Reduce player churn by 2% in Q3 among the top tier, measured by 30-day repeat visits.'

criteria.description: Clear Goal, Fuzzy Metrics: Outcome clear but KPIs undefined.
criteria.example: 'Improve the VIP guest experience,' without specific metrics.

criteria.description: Clear Problem, Vague Solution: Problem understood but scope undefined.
criteria.example: 'We know we have a problem with long lines at the buffet; can AI help?'

criteria.description: Ambiguous Scope: Stakeholders have conflicting expectations.
criteria.example: Marketing wants personalization, while Operations wants cost savings from the same project.

criteria.description: Hard Gate. Unclear Problem: The problem itself is unclear.
criteria.example: A vague request like 'Can we use AI to be more competitive?' with no business problem.

criteria.description: No risk; uses fully anonymous, aggregated data.
criteria.example: Analyzing aggregated slot machine performance data to identify popular games.

criteria.description: Low risk; involves PII but follows approved patterns.
criteria.example: A marketing project using player data where clear consent has been obtained.

criteria.description: Moderate risk; touches sensitive data requiring legal review.
criteria.example: A project involving security camera footage that requires ethical review.

criteria.description: High risk; borders on non-compliance, requiring significant rework.
criteria.example: A project difficult to make compliant with data privacy (GDPR/CCPA) rules.

criteria.description: Hard Gate. Project is non-compliant with gaming or data regulations.
criteria.example: A project proposing sharing player data with third parties without consent.
